Description: Limestone temple-relief of Ptolemy I offering to Hathor: Ptolemy I wears a bag wig and a single string of beads, and presents to Hathor the heraldic plants of Upper and Lower Egypt, respectively a lily-like sedge and a papyrus. The plants, which are rendered as stiff little baubles, may well depict royal gifts to the temple, made of gold and other precious materials. Hathor holds the papyrus scepter of a goddess and wears a vulture cap, topped by a platform that supported her emblematic cow horns and sun disk. Both figures look well fed, pleased with themselves and with each other. Traces of paint survive.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Prof Francis Llewellyn Griffith
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Hathor (Kom Abu Billo)
Curator's comments: Bibliography: K. Myśliwiec, 'Royal Portraiture of the Dynasties XXI-XXX' (Mainz am Rhein, 1988), 85, 126; pl. Topographie et religion dans le IIIe province de Basse Egypte, MIFAO 146, Cairo 2022, p. 106 bloc no. 8.
Bibliographic references: Russmann 2001 / Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum (138)
